STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER LANS ING ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980
February 14, 2025
Fred CHARLES Baker
JACKSON COUNTY YOUTH CENTER
930 FLEMING AVE,
JACKSON, MI, 49202-2534
Re: License #: CO380201204
SI #: 2025SIC0000179
Dear Mr. Baker:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Nabiha Rizk, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS/Division of Child Welfare Licensing
enclosure

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & R 400.10157 Health services; policies and procedures. Rule 157.
Section (1) A facility shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures that address all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical and dental care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Facility did not address Youth A being without medication until a
week after the youth ran out. Youth A suffered withdrawal
symptoms.
Investigation JJ Worker 2 was interviewed on 12/06/2024 via telephone. JJ
Worker reported Youth A was placed at the facility on 10/25/2024,
and she has only been assigned to Youth A for one month. Youth
A was previously placed at Vista Maria. She was informed that
Youth A needed to have a psychiatric evaluation before she can
get refills for one of her medications that requires a weekly
bloodwork script. Youth A was evaluated on 12/04/2024 and a
reoccurring blood work has been ordered.
Complainant was contacted via telephone 12/09/2024,
12/10/2024, 02/05/2025, and a voicemail was left requesting a call
back. Complainant didn’t respond or call back.
Administrator was interviewed on 12/12/2024 at the facility.
Administrator reported Youth A was placed at the facility on
10/25/2024 and they had an issue with getting her medication
refilled because of the medication requirement to have weekly
bloodwork done. He said it was a struggle getting her scheduled
for a psychiatric assessment at Lifeway because of the change of
placement. Youth A had a psychiatric assessment at Lifeway on
12/04/2024 and is back on her medication. Administrator reported
Supervisor is responsible for coordinating with the JJ Worker to
get youths medication refilled.
Supervisor was interviewed at the facility on 12/12/2024.
Supervisor confirmed Youth A did not get their psychotropic
medication for two weeks due to the medication requirement for
weekly bloodwork. He said Youth A was seen at the Center for
Health Center on 10/30/2024, but they would not provide the
bloodwork order because they wanted Youth A evaluated by a
psychiatrist. He said they reached out to Youth A’s previous
placement, Vista Maria, and the doctor at Vista Maria provided
one bloodwork order. Supervisor said he was coordinating with
2

Youth A’s JJ Worker 2 to get Youth A scheduled at Lifeway for an
evaluation, but it was a challenge due to the change of placement.
Supervisor said it is the responsibility of the JJ Worker to
coordinate and schedule psychiatric appointments.
Youth A was interviewed at the facility on 12/12/2024. Youth A
has been at the facility since 10/25/2024. Youth A reported she is
taking her medication daily, but there is one medication that she
was not taking because the facility ran out of it. Youth A could not
remember how long she went without taking the medication. She
said she has to do weekly blood work; the facility could not get her
bloodwork order. Youth A reported she did see a psychiatrist last
week, completed her blood work, and is now back on the
medication. Youth A denied any other issues or concerns.
Doctor was interviewed on 02/05/2025 via telephone. Doctor
reported she works at Lifeway and confirmed she completed a
psychiatric assessment on 12/04/2024 for Youth A, ordered
reoccurring bloodwork for Youth A, and has been prescribed
psychotropic medication Clozapine. Doctor reported based on her
assessment Youth A did not experience withdrawals as a result of
not taking her prescribed medication for two weeks.
ACCESS Supervisor was interviewed on 02/10/2025. She
confirmed that Youth A had an intake assessment completed on
12/02/2024 and had a psychiatric assessment on 12/04/2024. She
reported Lifeway provides psychiatric services, has immediate
appointments, and accepts walk-ins.
Documents Reviewed:
• Admission notes for Youth A date 10/25/2024. Youth A was
brought in by JJ Worker 2. Youth A had 5 or 6 packs of
medication. Supervisor asked JJ Worker 2 to get refills or
call Lifeway ASAP to schedule an appointment.
• Medical Note for Youth A dated 10/30/2025. Youth A was
taken to Center for Health Center, she has an order for
bloodwork. Doctor was concerned about her medication list
and recommended a trip to Lifeway.
• Medical Note for Youth A dated 11/07/2024 Youth A is
transported to get bloodwork done.
• Medical Note for Youth A dated 11/26/2024 Youth A went
to Center for Health Center to get her shoulder assessed.
She had an x-ray done.
• Medical Note for Youth A dated 12/04/2024. Youth went to
Lifeways today. Medical was refilled and she has a
3

standing order for weekly blood work draws. She is to be
seen in one month. No issues noted.
• Youth A’s medication log indicated Youth A did not take the
medication Clozapine 200 mg and 50 mg from 11/19/2024
thru 12/03/2024.
• Youth A’s Health Information Form 5921: Youth A is to take
Clozapine 200 mg daily at bedtime and Clozapine 50mg
daily in the morning.
• Youth A’s discharge summary from Vista Maria: Youth A
was discharged with 6 tablets of Clozapine 200mg and 5
tablets of Clozapine 50mg.
• Email from Nurse was received on 01/10/2025 that
confirmed Youth was discharged from Vista Maria on
10/25/2024, Youth A was discharged with 6 tablets of
Clozapine 200mg and a script was sent to Genoa
Healthcare for 30 tablets of Clozapine 200mg. One
bloodwork order was also issued to ensure medication refill
for Clozapine.
• Facility Program Statement states: While a minor is being
detained, they will receive medical screening.
• Facility medication distribution and request policy states:
when a resident reaches less than a five-day supply of
medication the Supervisor will attempt to contact the
resident’s parent/legal guarding and request a refill. If the
medication is prescribed through Genoa Healthcare, then
Genoa will be contacted about delivering refills for the
resident. If unable to speak to a parent/legal guardian at the
time of the call, a voicemail should be left indicating that the
resident is running low on medication and needs a refill.
Analysis The facility is in violation of the rule based on interviews and
documentation which shows Youth A went two weeks without her
prescribed medication. The agency policy and procedure for
health services is insufficient to meet the health care needs of the
youths.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
4
